target_text: "I’d like to say, in our team we also focus on the internal software quality. The final product may confirm to business needs and have fewer defects but it doesn’t always mean the internal quality is acceptable. We have to add the desires to maintain, understand and reuse code to evaluate quality."

Role_Team.Subject: Geography
Role_Team.positionality: As a Product Owner pursuing a master’s in Geography, I approach spatial-economic questions through a pragmatic lens, prioritizing actionable insights for decision-making. My research interest in Economics steers me toward regional development, market accessibility, and place-based policy evaluation, often privileging quantitative, GIS-enabled evidence. I recognize my epistemological assumptions—positivist-leaning and optimization-oriented—which may undervalue lived experience and alternative ontologies. The way questions are framed and how users respond guide my sampling, coding, and model choices, potentially amplifying dominant stakeholder voices. By foregrounding reflexivity and triangulation, I seek to balance efficiency with equity and contextual nuance in interpreting results.

Role_Team.Subject: Statistics
Role_Team.positionality: As a software developer pursuing bachelor’s-level study in statistics, I bring computational problem-solving and data-driven habits to economic inquiry. My research goal is to produce reproducible, statistically rigorous analyses that inform practical economic decisions. I recognize that my cultural background, personal experiences, and a developer’s efficiency mindset can bias variable selection, model choice, and preference for quantifiable outcomes. To mitigate this, I triangulate methods, document assumptions, and invite critique. The question and user responses further shape my framing, operationalization, and interpretation, prompting reflexive checks that align my methods with the study’s context and stakeholders’ perspectives.

Role_Team.Subject: Anthropology
Role_Team.positionality: I am a software developer pursuing a master’s-level inquiry, bringing a computational mindset to anthropological questions. Guided by anthropology (QS) and research interests in economics (NSF), I aim to examine how digital infrastructures mediate economic behavior and inequality. My practice is shaped by ethical and societal assumptions—valuing fairness, privacy, open access, and sometimes technological solutionism—which I interrogate through reflexivity. The framing of the Question and the User’s Response directs my attention to certain categories and language, potentially privileging measurable patterns over lived meanings. Consequently, my interpretations may foreground systems, incentives, and data, while I strive to center participant voices and cultural context.

Role_init_codebook.role: Reflective Researcher (PhD Candidate); Discipline: Computer Science—Software Engineering; NSF Interest: Software Engineering & Programming Languages; Bias: prioritizes internal quality attributes over defect/business-fit metrics

codebook.justification: From a software engineering lens, centers [internal software quality] as a value-laden dimension (ISO/IEC 25010) requiring subjective weighting.
As an SE-focused analyst, frames [maintain, understand and reuse code] as core criteria, privileging maintainability judgments over defect counts.
Positions [confirm to business needs] and [fewer defects] as necessary but insufficient, contesting outcome-only quality definitions.
Advocates to [add the desires] [to evaluate quality], expanding the rubric via context-specific, human-judged nonfunctional attributes.

As a qualitative SE researcher, the stress on [internal software quality] signals prioritization of structural attributes over external conformance. This emphasis is interpretive and relies on value-laden quality models.
Contrasting [confirm to business needs] and [have fewer defects] with [to evaluate quality] indicates a broader, multi-criteria lens. Weighting such criteria is subjective and theory-dependent.

Citing [maintain, understand and reuse code] centers maintainability, comprehension, and reuse as quality determinants. Assessing these soft attributes requires human judgment and contextualized heuristics.
The clause [the internal quality is acceptable] foregrounds negotiated thresholds of sufficiency. Acceptability is normatively set by teams and not objectively measurable.

Role_init_codebook.role: Reflective software engineering researcher (PhD level); QS: Computer Science; NSF: Human-Centered Computing/Software Engineering; Bias: prioritizes developer-centered NFRs over defect counts

codebook.justification: By emphasizing [the internal quality is acceptable], the speaker foregrounds subjective internal code health. Acceptability thresholds are socially constructed NFRs, negotiated beyond defect counts.
Referencing [maintain] signals maintainability as a core quality attribute. Maintainability assessments rely on expert heuristics (e.g., modularity, code smells), not a single ground truth.
Invoking [understand] centers developer cognition in quality evaluation. Comprehensibility is interpretive, varying with team expertise and conventions.
Stating [reuse code] frames quality in terms of future adaptability. Reusability involves contextual trade-offs and design intent, resisting purely objective measurement.

Agreed.definition: Maintainability-related attributes are central to assessing quality, evidenced by the addition of [maintain, understand and reuse code] as criteria 'to evaluate quality.'
The team explicitly prioritizes internal code health, focusing on [internal software quality] and whether [the internal quality is acceptable], not just outward outcomes.

Quality must be judged beyond business fit and defect counts: [The final product may confirm to business needs and have fewer defects but it doesn’t always mean the internal quality is acceptable.] and [We have to add the desires to maintain, understand and reuse code to evaluate quality.]

Disagreed.definition: Isolates [understand] as a standalone quality dimension; others subsume it under maintainability. Divergence: granularity split.
Elevates [reuse code] as its own intent/attribute rather than part of maintainability. Divergence: differing decomposition of internal quality facets.

Interprets [the internal quality is acceptable] as negotiated, team-specific thresholds; the text asserts acceptability but does not foreground social calibration. Divergence: interpretive framing vs. literal claim.

disagree_explain:
Disagreements: For Code Comprehensibility and Reusability, the Reflective SE researcher (PhD level) isolates [understand] and [reuse code] from [maintain, understand and reuse code], while the PhD Candidate and Qualitative researcher subsume them under Maintainability. For Acceptability Thresholds, the Qualitative and Reflective SE roles treat [the internal quality is acceptable] as team-negotiated, whereas the PhD Candidate reads it literally, emphasizing evaluation expansion over social calibration.
Click on the option under Disagreed Items on the left to start the discussion

Closing.definition: Maintain a distinct Code Comprehensibility tag because the source explicitly enumerates understand alongside maintain and reuse under internal software quality. Treating understand as a separate desire improves annotation precision and avoids conflating comprehension with maintenance or reusability.

All roles concur the text explicitly enumerates 'maintain, understand and reuse code' as criteria for evaluating internal software quality, treating reuse as a parallel facet. Retaining 'Reusability Emphasis' preserves this distinction and supports clearer, more consistent annotation despite minor taxonomic ambiguity.

Retain the code because the passage asserts acceptability in a team context ('in our team', 'the internal quality is acceptable') while providing only criteria ('maintain, understand and reuse code') without calibrated thresholds. This tag flags acceptability claims lacking defined levels, reducing ambiguity and improving annotation consistency.
